editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by idREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Sir Griffin Meriddock Lord Geoffrey Powis Sir Gosselen Denville Sir Evan Griffin John a Kent Ranulph; Earl of Chester Oswen; son of Ranulph Amery; Lord Mortaigue Countess of Chester Marian; daughter of Countess of Chester Sidanen; daughter of Llwellen Earl of Pembroke Earl of Morton Turnop Hugh; a Sexton Thomas; a Taberer Spurling Robert Will Shrimp; John a Kent's boy Servant to Ranulph Llewellen; Prince of North Wales John a Cumber Abbot of Chester Servant Multiple speakers Follower 1 Antique 2 Antique 3 Antique 4 Antique Song Speaker unknown

front.head: The Book of John a Kent & John a Cumber

div2.head: Scena i…
div2.stage: Enter Sir Griffin Meriddock of So…wales, & Ieffrey…ow…

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Powesse, vain persuadest thou patience,
In vain thou dreamest of likely remedies,
In vain thou of this or that conceit.
wind words, are vainer than the wind,
Only our weapons must effect our weal.

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.l: As hitherto my Lord I have entreated,
So for a while, I pray ye be advised.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Advised? why what advise can Powesse yield?
Is not Sidanen with the Earl's consent,
and Prince Llwellens grant, affied to Moorton?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: yea, so Pembrooke hath their grant for Marian: But.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: But what? Even while we thus stand wasting idle words,
Pembrook and Moorton shall possess our loves.
Our loves exclaim against our cowardice,
Our cowardice to our eternal shame,
In England wales and Scotland shall be sung,
by every jigging mate, our foes among.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Nor English, welsh or Scottish shall reprove,
Lord Ieffrey Powesse with base cowardice.
As much (Prince Griffin) as the proudest dare
dares Powesse for his Marians liberty.
yet not with rashness or unbridled heat,
discretion must be used, the cause is great.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Great cause indeed, when fair Sidanens eyes,
dimmed with the source of her continual tears,
mixing those tears amongst the mournful ink,
That writ the cause of her lament and mine,
seems this paper weeping to entreat:
And then no marvel though the cause be great

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: But greater cause, our countries cause I mean,
If we should manage arms, as you still urge,
And so by force, from noble Chesters Court,
against his will, fetch our well-willing loves;
we may be held as traitors to the King,
that durst invade his towns in time of peace.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: To see how Powesse casts beyond the Moon,
As if the King would deal in these affairs.
Or if he did, is it like his Majesty,
would suffer fathers by compelling awe:
to force their children from their souls affect?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: But if his highness subjects should be slain,
as in rough rescue it must needs fall out,
he will not have the meanest guiltless die:
but blood for blood shall duly be repayed.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Then Powesse, lest such danger should betide:
you are content the Ladies shall be lost?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Not so Prince Griffin, then I would have stayed,
and not have come so near to Chesters Court.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: By our Lady Sir, and we are much the near.
we two belike, by your complotting wit,
shall front the Earl of Chester in his Court,
And spite of Chesters strong inhabitants,
Through west chester, meekly in our hands,
lead my Sidanen and your Marian,
while both our Rivals, and their following train,
Sheeplike stand shivering at our wrathful looks.
Beshrew me, but ye have a passing head,
All naturally are your reasons, full of sense.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: If we obtain them, you will leave jesting then

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: yea that I will. But can ye tell me when?

div2.stage: Enter Sr. Gosselin denvyle, Sr. Euan Griff…, and I o…

sp.speaker: Gosselen
sp.l: what
have company,
trust will purge your melancholy.
welcome Gentlemen, you seem no less,
be not offended at my salutations,
that bid ye stand, before I say God speed.
for in plain terms, speed what your speed may be,
Such coin you have, both must and shall with me.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: How now Lord Ieffrey? what companion have we here?
he seems some thief.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No thief Sir, but an honest bon companion.
Never draw your weapons, rather trust your feet,
And yet ye cannot hence, but at my pleasure.
what needs all this? yield, if I bid ye yield.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Thou shouldest be Iohn a'Kent, thou art so peremptory,
for Iohn a'Kent is a bold merry knave.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: It is happy then he is no very knave.
I am the man, what say ye to Iohn a'Kent?

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.l: I am Ieffrey Lord Powesse, thy masters friend,
And this Sr. Griffin Meriddock, Prince of Southwales.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: why then I know ye both, and welcome both,
Mr. these are the guests you look for, whom had I not well guessed at,
they had for welcome got a cudgelling.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: welcome my Lord, and welcome noble Prince.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Thanks good Sr. Gosselen denvyle, and Sr. Euan Griffin,
I trust the men you promised me are ready.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: for my part, seven score bowmen, wight and tall,
have I lodged the wood, near to the river of dee.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: And I threescore as strong, with hooks and bills,
that to three hundred will not turn their backs.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: But can ye tell us any news from Chester?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Cold news for you my Lords, there is at Chester,
The Earl of Pembrooke, and the Scottish Moorton,
the one shall have Llwellens fair Sidanen,
the other Marian, good old Chesters daughter.
and both these weddings finished tomorrow.

sp.speaker: … Griffin.
sp.l: No more of that my friend, thou slayest me with these news.
hearst thou this Powesse? this did I foredoom:
now all your wise devices come too late.

sp.speaker: …Gosselen
sp.l: Content ye good my Lord, no whit too late,
here is a lad on whom we do rely,
for sly conveyance of the Ladies hither,
full of conceit he is, and deeply seen,
in secret arts, to work for your avail.

sp.speaker: ….Griffin.
sp.l: Canst thou my friend, from forth the vaults beneath,
call up the ghosts of those long since deceased?
Or from the upper region of the air:
fetch swift winged spirits to effect thy will?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Can you my Lord, and you, and you, and you,
go to the venison, for your suppers dressed:
and afterwards go lay ye down to rest?

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.l: how then sweet Iohn? all this thou knowest we can,
and what thou canst we have no doubt at all:
but what thou wilt, that gladly would we learn.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I will tomorrow bring you Marian,
and you Prince Griffin your beloved Sidanen.
will this content ye?

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: As all the world cannot content me more.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: why then I pray ye be content to go,
And frolic cheerily, for it shall be so

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: I warrant ye my Lords, come let us in.

sp.speaker: I…hn.
sp.l: So, they must banquet, I unto my business.
But let me muse a little on this love,
full of many fears, so sundry joys,
now hence, now hither diversely distract,
But Iohn a'Kent what talkest thou
rather mind thou the pleasing joys .
And since so good a subject they present,
upon these lovers practise thou thy wit.
help, hinder, give, take back, turn, overturn,
deceive, bestow, breed pleasure, discontent.
yet comicly conclude, like Iohn a'Kent.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore Ranulphe Earle of Chester, Oswen his sonn young Amery Lord Mortaigue, wth them the Countesse, her daught… Marian, and fayre Sidanen. At another doore enter the Earles Pembrooke, Moorton and their trayne.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: All health be to the noble Earl of Chester,
his Countess and these honourable Ladies,
whom one by one I humbly gratulate,
wishing to them their happy hearts content.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: The Like doth Pembrook to this goodly train.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Earl Moorton, and my noble Lord of Pembrooke,
whose presence brings contentment to my soul
and adds true honour to your noble names:
for having kept your vows inviolate,
how you are welcome, words shall not explain,
but such as best beseems your entertain.
your father Madam, will be here this night,
Or early the morning, well I wot,
for such provision hath he sent before,
as shows himself will not be far behind.
And sith it is our ancient English guise,
the Bridegrooms should upon the wedding day,
come from some distant place to fetch their Brides,
my house at Plessye is for you prepared.
Thence to the Castle shall you walk along
And at Saint Iohns shall be solemnised,
the nuptials of your honours, and these virgins.
for to that Church, Edgar, once Englands King,
was by eight Kings, conquered by him in wars:
rowed royally on Saint Iohn Baptist day.
In memory of which pomp, the Earls our ancestors,
have to that Church been noble benefactors.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: Eight Kings row one? that was great pomp indeed.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: One of them was of Scotland, as I read,
the Irish, and the dane two more beside,
and five of Britain, all subdued by him.
To see that Church will greatly joy my mind,
because I there a greater joy shall find.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: why looks Sidanen sad? why sighs she so?

sp.speaker: Sidanen
sp.l: Pardon my Lord, such things you may not know.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: She not mislikes her choice I hope of me.

sp.speaker: Sidanen
sp.l: No God forbid. although you are not he.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: why then look cheerily, as Sidanen should,

sp.speaker: Sidanen.
sp.l: I do my Lord. And better if I could.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Madam, the Scottish Lord hath got a gracious look,
but Pembrooke is not half so happy yet.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Sister, you wrong the noble Earl with frowns

sp.speaker: Amery
sp.l: My Lord content ye, women fain dislike,
where their affections bear the highest regard.

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: You are too young my Lord, to judge so soundly,

sp.speaker: Amery.
sp.l: I find it writ by them that judged profoundly

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: Books may beguile ye.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: My Lord, that cut came roundly.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Your sadness tell, if I may know the cause,

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Methinks my Lord the custom is too hard,
when lovers meet, so suddenly to part,

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Tomorrow's joy will end that bitter smart,

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: To see ye no more, how would it ease my heart?

sp.speaker: Chester
sp.l: well noble Lords, for this time break we off,
Son and Lord Amery, you will be their guide.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: yea my good Lord, then go we Gentlemen.
Cousin, now we are alone,
Let entreat to know the secret cause,
that moves these passions more than overpensive,
which were not wont in you to work such change.
If in my power to counsel, or prevent,
there rest a mean, let me but know your minds,
and what I may shall surely be effected,
to either of your longing hearts, content.

sp.speaker: Sydanan.
sp.l: Madam, your tender care and kind affect,
assures Sidanen of your honours faith.
In brief my noble Aunt, this is the cause,
why poor Sydanen is disconsolate,
That she must leave her country and her kin,
and pass to Scotland with the Earl of Moorton.

sp.speaker: Countesse
sp.l: Cousin, his kindness soon will calm this grief,
and therefore cast these cares behind thy back.
But what old man is this comes toward us?

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Kent like an aged Hermit

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Ladies, if crooked age, and homely weeds,
breed not contempt, vouchsafe I humbly pray,
your charitable comfort to sustain,
a little longer these spent withered limbs,
that numbed through chillness of my frost-bit blood,
which six score winters hath resisted storms,
and just so many times the summers heat.
Now quaking like the wind-blown bough for strength,
witness that all things yield to time at length.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: how much I grieve that these thy silver hairs,
should in extremest age feel taste of want,
And this thy furrowed face, with tears distained,
shall well appear: for thou shalt in with us.
These feeble limbs with age so overworn,
shall find repose, and not be left forlorn.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: father, receive this little gift of me.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: And here old man, take this to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: As many blessings light upon you three,
as cares and crosses have befallen to me.
But much I fear, if art may judge aright
some ill is toward these twain this present night.

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: what sayst thou father? art thou a man of skill?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lady, in youth I studied hidden arts,
and profited in Chiromancy much,
If sight be not obscured through natures weakness,
I can, for once I could discourse by favour,
and rules of palmistry ensuing chances.

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: Good father tell my fortune if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: Nay mine I pray thee first, I asked thee first.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Strive not fair Ladies, show me both your hands
for your complexions seem to be alike.
Nay let me see, both your affections are alike.
Blush not, but tell me, are ye not both betrothed,
to two great Lords, without your parents knowledge?

sp.speaker: Countesse
sp.l: They are betrothed indeed, but with their parents knowledge,
and both tomorrow must be married.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Now God forbid, woe is me to think thereon.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: why father? I pray thee speak

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Good Madam pardon me, let me be gon,
and leave the God of heaven to work his will

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: Nay stay good father, I pray thee tell the worst.

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: My heart doth throb, sweet father then resolve us.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sith you compel me Ladies, I will speak,
and what I say, believe it on your lives.
If ere the Sun tomorrow cheer the earth,
you wash not at Saint winifrides fair spring,
your lily hands, and list the holy voice,
which will resolve ye of your loves sweet choice:
I may not say what shall ye both betide,
but harder fortune never befell fair Bride.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Alas the spring is three miles hence at least
and now thou seest the night approacheth on

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Let not the distance hinder them to go,
lest they and you wish that ye had done so.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: father, I have some reason to believe thee,
by what I must keep secret to myself,
And but my Lord condemns these ancient rules,
religiously observed in these parts:
I would crave leave for them to travel thither,
for many have misdone that did it not.

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: rather than hard mishap should us befall,
it were good we were acquainted therewithal.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Good mother, this fair evening let us go,
we will come again before my father know.

sp.speaker: Countesse
sp.l: well, go ye shall, and I along with ye,
had we some trusty friend to be our guide.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ladies, although my limbs be not so strong,
my bones near marrowless, bloodless my veins:
yet use hath made me perfect in the way.
And if your honours deign so old a guide:
So speed my soul as shall to you betide.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: None better. But what hour of night is best?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: when twice two hours the daughters of the night,
have driven their Eban chariot through the air,
and with their dusky wings breathed calmy rest,
upon the eyelids of each living thing:
The silver shining horned lamp doth rise,
by whose clear light we may discern the path,
wherein though lamely now I seem to plod
yet will I guide ye safely to the spring.
And for your coming at the back gate wait,
till when Gods benison protect ye all.

sp.speaker: Cou…tesse.
sp.l: well father, we will come, upon mine honour.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: The hour is one at midnight, fail us not.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: fail ye? i'faith that were a silly jest,
Our sport would fail, if I should fail mine hour
But hushed, here comes my hotspur, and Lord Powesse

div2.stage: Enter Sr. Griffin, and Lord Powesse.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: See Powesse, here is Iohn a'Kent, decked in a Pilgrims weed

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: why how now Iohn? turned green to friar's gray?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: what madness makes ye come so far this way?
The town is beset, our purpose is descried
and now I see your coming made all spied.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: help us to scape unto thy masters cave.
yet ere we go, tell me, sawest thou Sydanen

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I saw her: but you shall never see her more.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: why so sweet Iohn? what? is Sydanen dead?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: Is she fled?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: Is Moorton and Sydanen married?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: wherefore then shall not I again behold her?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Because your honour is too full of heat,
and by your rashness will discover all,
wherefore shift as ye can, for I will leave ye.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Nay I pray thee Iohn, tell us the truth of all.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: The troth is, if ye mean to meet the Ladies
and go along where I shall lead ye,
And as I shall appoint, so follow my directions.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: But will they come?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: They will, if you will go.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: But how?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: why on their feet, I know no other way.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: But when?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Nay then we shall be troubled, when? how? where?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: I pray thee tell us Iohn without delay.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Content ye Lords, I will tell ye on the way, come let us go.

sp.speaker: Sr. Griffin
sp.l: Iohn, I will renown thee, if it fall out so.

div2.stage: Enter Turnop wth his crewe of Clownes, & a Minstrell.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: Nay never talk of it, Hugh the Sexton stutters, let him read
the first line, or see if he can say the speech, that daws our
Churchwarden made in praise of his Mill horse.

sp.speaker: Hugh
sp.l: It makes no matter, I think myself the wisest because I am
Sexton, and being Sexton, I will say the speech I made
myself.

sp.speaker: Tom tabrer
sp.l: hear ye Hugh, be not so forward, take a little vise of your minstrel.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And well said Thomas Tabrer, you have scression, speak on.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: One of the wisest of us must speak, and either it must be Hugh or Turnop. Now, Hugh is Sexton, an office of retority I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: yea, that is when he is in the Belfry, not else.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Hugh Hugh, Hugh shall speak the speech to the Lords.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: But Turnop being my Lords man, his hogheard, his familiarity
servant, he in my mind is not only fit, but also accessory
for the ration making, then Turnop say I.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Turnop, Turnop, we will have none but Turnop.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: well, for your wisdoms, in choosing me, I rest quoniam dignitatis vestrum primarion , as the Poet Pediculus saith, at the next vestry, bound to defer ye to several local places.

sp.speaker: Spurling.
sp.l: how now Hugh? are ye put down i'faith?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: That is because he has a little more learning, and has borrowed
the ushers old coat to grace himself withal

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.l: O, take heed of learning while ye live, it is a gandly matter.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p:
ffrater meum amantissime Hugo the Bellringer, the
epitheton Barra cans, as much to say, no man can bar his chance, persuadeth you to remit, or submit or admit yourself, to the cry of your brethren. How say ye then fellow mates in arms, this our show, who shall be the speaker?

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Turnop Turnop, we will have none but Turnop.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: Then let us set forward, for now it is upon the Lords coming. Thomas, firk it with your fiddle. Spurling, you play the Moore, advance up your Tun, and Robert, hold your porringer right, lest you spill the conceit, for here they come.

div2.stage: Enter Pembrook, Moorton, Oswen, Amery, to them this crew… marching, one drest lik a Moore, wth a Tun painted with… yellow oker, another with a Porrenger full of water an… a pen it, Turnop speaketh the Oration.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: Like to the Cedar in the lofty Sea,
or milk white mast upon the humble mount:
So hearing that your honours came this way,
Of our rare wits we came to give account.
for when as princes pass through petty towns
they must be welcomed, lest they term us clowns.
Our presents precious, first the golden Tun,
borne by that monstrous Murrian blackamoor,
Mortonus Earlus in thy praise is done.
This shining brook hemmed in with this fierce shore
That hath
Is peerless Penbrook, if I rove not wide
As for the two last rimes, right worshipful, and
wise, by the error of the Author overslipped, is the
mothy Turnop the Orator newly corrected, to wit
This princely pen up prancing by the sides,
And so we wish ye both two blessed brides.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: My Lords, my fathers tenants after their homely guise,
welcome ye with their country merriment,
How bad soever, yet must ye needs accept it.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Else Oswen were we very much to blame,
thanks gentle friends, here drink this for my sake

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: And this for me, commending your great pains,
which more liberal sort we will requite.

sp.speaker: Amery.
sp.l: May it please ye Lords to walk into the Castle
and there at full we will see their other sports.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: with all my heart, go, we will follow ye.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: Before you go, in name of all this train
Turnop accepts your gold, and thanks you for your pain.
Thomas, lead the vanguard with your easement, you with
our hyperbolical devices, march in the middest. And if
Lords will see us make them merry, ere we will want devise
we will make them weary, march on.

div2.head: Scena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter at one doore Iohn a'Kent, hermit lyke, as before, at another enter the Countesse, Sydanen and Marian

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Promise is kept, the Ladies are come forth,
the ambush ready that shall soon surprise them.
See Madam; I am ready to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Gramercies father, lead thou on the way,
and give good counsel to my sweet young Cousin.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Madam I warrant ye she will take none bad.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Or good or bad, she taketh all from me.
Madam, would you vouchsafe me so much favour:
as she, so I would gladly talk with him.

sp.speaker: Cou…tesse.
sp.l: Let them alone, ye shall have time enough.

sp.speaker: Sydan en .
sp.l: Nay forward father, let me hear the rest.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Then Madam, to omit all ambages,
I know it, for mine Art assureth me,
you are contracted to the South wales Prince:
and wronging him, you wrong yourself much more.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: for Gods sake softly, lest the Countess hear.
True hast thou said, but by my fathers grant,
The Earl of Moorton must Sydanen wed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: That is as Sydanen will, as I suppose

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: will I, or nil I, all is one to him,
he is a Prince, and he hath promised it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: you are a Princess, and have promised no.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Earl Moorton with my father is in favour,
and hath his word, that I shall be his wife.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But hath he yours?

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Never all my Life.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I know not Lady how the world is changed.
when I was young they wooed the daughter first,
and then the father, when they had her grant,
which could they get, why so, if not, why then,
her word was worth the meeting where and when.

sp.speaker: Countesse
sp.l: why how now daughter? why draw you so near?

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: She talks too long, and somewhat would I hear.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Bide you with me, till she have made an end

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Pray God this talk to our desire may tend.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But would you go with him, if he were here?

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: would I desire to be accounted chaste?
reverenced for virtue, as for naturally gifts?
would I ask strength for these my feeble limbs,
if some fierce Tiger had me in pursuit?
would I shun fear? would I require content?
or wish the endless happiness of heaven?
If these I would, then that as much I would.
for what is fame, health, joy, or aught to me,
except with him that gives them all to me?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Madam enough, is Marian of your mind?

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: yea father. She to Powesse, I to Prince Griffin writ,
but when no answer either could receive,
resolvedly thus we set down our rest.
Tomorrow when the nuptial feast is past,
And that the Bridegrooms do expect their Brides:
A strong confection both we have prepared,
of deadly Aconite with them to drink.
Besides, a letter drawn, to show the cause,
why so revengefully we sought their deaths,
and so despairingly lost our own lives.
This made us both hold thee in such regard,
when thou foretoldest of dangers to ensue.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: This resolution doth renown ye both,
but your fair stars affords ye better fortune.
And for my words may yield but dallying hope,
see what is done in twinkling of an eye.
sp.stage: Enter denvyle, Griff. Powesse, and trayne
sp.l: Those Lords for whom you twain would lose your lives,
Come boldly here to challenge their fair wives.
Madam dismay not, here no harm is meant,
Both they and you, welcome to Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: vild Sorcerer, hast thou betrayed us thus?
hiding thy treason with so good pretence?
Prince Griffin, and Lord Powesse, be assured,
If otherwise than nobly you entreat,
My princely Cousin, and my noble child;
it will be wreaked on your presuming heads.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: you wrong them Madam, if you misconceit,
that you or they shall be unnobly used.
you are brought hither to no other end,
but that their behaviour you might all commend.
Ask but the Ladies, if they will depart,
I will bring ye where I had ye, yea, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Then go sweet Cousin, daughter, let us hence,
for fear worse happen on this foul offence.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: The worst is past, let happen now what shall,
I will keep Sidanen, or lose life and all.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: And if Sydanen willingly depart,
from her prince Griffin, joy never have her heart.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: I hope my Marian is of selfsame mind,

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Else were thy love requited too unkind.
Now mother, would you were at home again,
we both are where we wished ourselves full fain.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Then questionless, this happed by your consent,
And well I wot, these noble Gentlemen,
Are honoured in your hearts before the other,
Sith your endeavours then so happy prove.
Never let me be hinderer of true love.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Madam, now speak ye like a loving mother,
And like Sydanens honourable Aunt.
Oppose this question, and be judge yourself,
Say you were troth plight where you liked best,
could ye i'faith so great a wrong digest:
As but for me had happened to these Ladies?
In to the Castle then, and frolic there
And what should have been done, to these sweets sorrow,
shall to their joy be finished here tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: Come Madam, favour me to be your guide,
you shall find all things here to your content.
And though my Lord the Earl hold off aloof,
and may dislike what we do for his honour:
Be you but pleased, we will never seek no other,
for though we the father yet we have the

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Let it be so good Aunt, and I shall pray,
for this good walk, you may live many a day.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: These speeches are vain, I pray ye be gon,
and entertain them, as this kindness merits.
Leave me awhile, to gratulate your feast,
with some rare merriment, or pleasing jest.
will ye be gon? ye do the Ladies wrong,
here in the air to chat with them so long.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Come sweet Sydanen I will be thy guide,
Moorton shall look him now another Bride.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: And so shall Pembrooke, now I am possessed
Of Marian, whom I ever loved best

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Here is love and love, Good Lord, was never the like,
but must these joys so quickly be concluded?
Must the first Scene make absolute a play?
no cross? no change? what? no variety?
One brunt is past, alas, what is that in love?
where firm affection is most truly knit,
the love is sweetest, that most tries the wit.
And by my troth, to sport myself awhile,
The disappointed Bridegrooms, these possessed,
the fathers, friends, and other more beside,
that may be used to furnish up conceit,
I will set on work in such an amorous war,
as they shall wonder whence ensues this jar.
O that I had some other like myself,
to drive me to sound policies indeed.
There is one Scotland, termed Iohn aCumber,
that overreached the devil by his skill,
had Moorton brought him to have sped his love,
I would have tried which should the master prove.
But since myself must pastime with myself,
I will anger them, be it but to please myself.
Sirrah Shrimp.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: Anon Sir, what is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Thus Sirrah. To Chester get ye gon,
They are yet asleep, that shall be waked anon.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: I go sir.

div2.stage: Enter Turnop, Hugh, Tom Tabrer, will the boy, and Spurling wth their Consort

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nay either let it be as Mr. Turnop will have, or by my troth, fair and I will go no further, either let us have credit or no credit

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: You have said as much as be said neighbour Thomas, and that not learnedly, but lovingly withal. Master Turnop, the Lords were pontifically pleased with your oration yesterday, that the Ladies morrow remaineth altogether at your disposition.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: why then thus my muse hath majestically, or minstricallically written in praise of fair Sydanen, and she being appointed to be married this day she ought to have the maidenhead of my muse, before she lose the abselutidico, as much to say in welsh or english, as her rose mary branch.

sp.speaker: Spurling.
sp.p: But has Will learned it perfectly? I tell you, she is a Lady of some scression, and looks that the song of Sydanen should be well performde

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: Goodman Spurling, though you be purblind, and thereby are favoured for the gross errors committed in your vocation; yet I pray ye, commit yourself to your music, as for the song, let it pass upon my strive, with this addition, He mihi quod domino, non licet ire tuo

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: when then tune all, for it draws toward day; and if we wake not the
Brides, why then it is worth nothing.
To add one good morrow more to your bed sides,

div2.stage: they play, the boy sings the welsh song.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: Timothie Turnop bids, Good morrow both the Brides.
Now to the Bridegrooms, and then my hearts look for a largess

sp.speaker: Shrimpe.
sp.l: why now is Shrimpe the height of his bravery,
that he may execute some part of his masters knavery.
Sound forth your music to the Bridegrooms sorrow,
for I will sing them but a sour good morrow.

div2.stage: a Song of the Brydes losse.
They play, and the boy singes, wheart the Bridegroomes come foorth in their nightgownes and kerchers on their heades, to them Oswen… Amery making them selues ready.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: what song is this, to flout me to my face?
is fair Sydanen gon, and left me in disgrace?

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Peasants, what mean ye to delude us so?
Is Marian and Sydanen gon, say yea, or no?

sp.speaker: Shrimpe.
sp.l: Are ye so hot? chafe ye so suddenly?
Nay pause awhile, I will fetch ye company.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: why my Lords, do ye ask us if the Ladies be gon or no?
If they be not in their beds it is more than we know.
villain thou liest, thou sungest a song of sorrow.

sp.speaker: …urnop.
sp.l: my Lord you lie, we played ye but a good morrow.
And seeing for our good wills, ye do us this wrong:
Let us to the Brides, to have money for our song.

sp.speaker: Oswen
sp.l: How now my Lords, what sudden noise is this?
Is fair Sydanen and my Sister fled?

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: These wretches that so sung, do now deny it.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: Let us talk a word or two awhile, I pray ye be quiet.
did ye not yesternight disturb your head,
with winum vinum ere ye went to bed?
That makes ye in your sleep to rise and walk,
or at the least, thus idiot-like to talk?

div2.stage: Enter the Earle of Chester his night gowne, and Shrimpe following aloofe of, some seruaunts wth him.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Can their departure be to all unknown?
Villains why speak ye not? did no-one see them?

sp.speaker: [i. Seruaunt.]
sp.l: Not any one my Lord that we can hear of.
Belike they went forth at the garden gate,
we found it open, therefore we suspect it.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: My Lord and father, are you up so soon?
where is my Sister? where is fair Sydanen?

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Nay, where is thy mother boy, ask that withal,
for she, thy Sister, and my lovely Niece,
this night are gon, and no-one can tell whither.
As I lay slumbering, well near half awake,
under my window did I hear a voice,
saying, rise Chester, for this wedding day,
is disappointed now another way.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: And a Song, the like was told to us,
by these base slaves, that now deny the same.
But yet my Lord, I hope it is not so?

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: That they are gon my Lords, it is true, I know.
But camest these news from you? why speak ye not?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Thomas, you are the ancientest man, I pray ye make answer for us all.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.p: My Lord, I hope it is not unknown to your worships that I have lived a poor professor of music in this parish this forty years, and no man could ever burden me with the value of two pence, that ye should now lay three wenches at once to my charge, I will not say: how much it grieves me, but between God and your conscience be it.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: Nay but hear ye my Lord, do ye as it were seem in good sound sadness, to tell us for a certainty that the Brides are gon? and that we, as
sp.l: it were should have some occasion to know thereof?

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: So say these Lords, they lay it to your charge.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: why then my Lords both great and small,
know that ye wrong not one, but all
which way soever they have betook them,
If they be gon, you may go look them.
And if they be not to be found,
you have lost your wives I will hold ye a pound.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Away then villains, raise up all my men,
bid them take horse, and post forth every way.
By some foul treason are they led from hence,
My wife else would not with this fault dispense.
Away I say, and trouble us no longer,

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: why now this gear doth cotton in right kind,
these news I wot will please my masters mind.

div2.stage: Enter Llwellen, his trayne, and Iohn a Cumber a loofe off.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: But here comes one whom this concerns so near,
that he will search the depth of this bold wrong.
Princely Llwellen, and my noble friend,
hither thou comest by loyal promise bound,
to solemnise thy daughters nuptial rights
But fair Sydanen and Earl Chesters daughters,
are with the aged Countess parted hence,
whither or how, as yet we cannot learn.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: why then my friend, thy tidings are too true,
unhappy man, is this my welcome hither?

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: My Lord, can he say anything of their departure?
Speak gentle friend, and ease our doubtful minds.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Ease them I cannot, but disease them more,
They are where you shall never see them more.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: how meanest thou friend? dally not I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Prince Griffin of Southwales hath got Sydanen,
Lord Powesse hath your daughter Marian.
And at Sr. Gosselen deuyles Castle, not far hence,
Before your Countess, who went with them thither:
this day their marriage must be consummate.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: what sayst thou? hath my Countess wronged me so?
and is this treachery by her consent?

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: No my good Lord, Know ye one Iohn a'Kent?
A man whom all this British Isle admires:
for his rare knowledge in the deepest arts?
By policy he trained them from this place,
they simply thinking no such hidden guile,
but at Saint winifrides fair hallowed spring,
to pay last tribute of their maiden vows,
went with the Countess, and that subtle guide,
So each of you may now go look his Bride.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: Let us to horse, and gather able troupes,
that may engirt the Castle round about.
Proud Griffin, Powesse, and the rest shall know,
I will not pocket this injurious wrong,
which I will rate at price of their best blood,
And his that hath so overreached us all.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: fie my good Lord, nay now ye grow too hot.
talk ye of horse, of men and multitudes?
when raise the very powerfulest strength ye can,
yet all is too weak to deal with that one man?
Had ye a friend could equal him Art,
control his cunning, which he boasts so on:
then were there hope of their recovery,
what else ye do, will help but slenderly.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: I will post to Scotland for brave Iohn a'Cumber,
the only man renowned for magic skill.
Oft have I heard, he once beguiled the devil,
and his Art could never find his match.
Come he with me, I dare say, Iohn a'Kent,
And all the rest shall this foul fact repent.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: were he here now my Lord, it would do well.
But if he come when everything is done
No credit by the matter can be won.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: My Lord, go you and fetch that famous man,
The Prince and I will forthwith to the Castle,
where calling them to parley on the walls,
we will promise that they shall enjoy the Ladies
with our consent, if but a seven-night space
they will adjourn the day of marriage,
sound reasons we will allege to urge them to it.
then you returned with him that never failed,
you have your wish, and Iohn in cunning quailed.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Be it so. My Lord, I will bear ye company,
not doubting but to speed successfully.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: I will save my Lord that labour. Here is Iohn a'Cumber,
enticed to England by the wondrous fame,
that everywhere is spread of Iohn a'Kent,
And seeing occasion falleth out so well,
I may do service to my Lord hereby:
I make him my protector this case.
what he hath done for many days together,
by Art I know, as you have seen some proof.
I will make no brags, but we two Iohns together,
will tug for mastery, therefore came I hither.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: The welcomest man that ever came to me,
And this kind love will Moorton well requite
for Gods sake let us lose no time in vain,
it is broad day light, sweet Iohn bestir thee now.
for never thy help could come in greater need.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: All you to horse. I will meet ye on the way.
My Lord, some of those merry lads gave you good morrow,
command to follow ye, I must employ them.
So get ye gon, and leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Chester
sp.l: we go Iohn. Come Gentlemen, away.
Now Iohn a'Kent, much have I heard of thee
envying fame
what art thou doing? very seriously,
plotting downs pastimes to delight the Ladies.
Then have amongst ye, you Sir have begun,
My turn is next before your sports be done.

div1.head: tertius.
div1.stage: Enter Sr. Griffin, Powesse, Gosselen and Euan

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: I cannot blame ye Lords to stir so early,
considering what occasions are in hand.
Loves long pursuit, at length to be requited
with the due guerdon to continued hope
And such by means of friendly Iohn a'Kent,
shall yield you both your several hearts content.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: yea, but the Countess and the other Ladies,
I doubt were wearied with so late a walk.
for as it seems they are not stirring yet,
And little kindness were it to disease them,
before themselves think best to leave their chamber.
But say Prince Griffin, whereon do ye muse?
you not mislike Sydanen is so near?
Nor you, that Marian bears her company.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Sir Euan, I will be plain, and tell ye what I thought.
I deeply did conceit within myself,
Lord Moortons passions he will act this morning:
when news is brought him that his bride is gon.
Think ye he will not curse the fatal hour:
began so sweet, and now falls out so sour?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Nay let my Rival bear him company,
And good old Chester, for his forwardness:
in seeking to deceive me of my wife.
But what will he imagine of his Countess?
She is gon from Court, and no man can tell whither:
and cold their suit, should they pursue them hither.

sp.speaker: Gosselen
sp.l: Thereof you may be bold; but much I muse
where Iohn a'Kent bestows him all this while.
He is so careful of his coy conceits,
to suit this solemn day as it should be:
that for your sakes, I know it shall excel,
at least he labours all things may be well.

div1.stage: Enter Iohn a Cumber lyke Iohn a Kent.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: See where he comes, deep pondering with himself,
important matters, we must not disturb him,
but give him leave, till his own leisure him.
Silence, methinks I hear sweet melody,
And see he sets the Castle gate wide ope,
Stand we aloof, and note what followeth.

div1.stage: Musique whi… he opens the doore ffrom one end of the Stage enter an antique queintly disguysde and coming dauncing before them, singes.

sp.speaker: i. Antique.
sp.l: when wanton love had walked astray,
then good regard began to chide:
And meeting her upon the way,
says wanton lass you must abide.
for I have seen many years,
That sudden love breeds sullen fears;
Shall I never while I live keep my girl at school:
She hath wandered to and fro,
further than a Maid should go,
Shall she never while she lives make me more a fool

div1.stage: …a ducking curtesy ~~
exit into the C…

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: you little think who it is that sung this song?

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: No Iohn, I pray thee tell us who it is.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: why Prince Llwellen, come to his daughters wedding
Is he her father, and not worth the bidding?

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: Thou dost but jest Iohn, I hope it is not so.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: I say it is. Here comes another, let us see if him I know.

div1.stage: ffrom the other end of the Stage, enter another antique, as the first.

sp.speaker: 2. Antique.
sp.l: In a silent shade, as I sate a-sunning,
there I heard a Maid grievously complain:
Many moans she made amongst her sighs still coming
all
Then her aged father, counselled her the rather
to consent where he had placed his mind:
But her peevish mother, brought her to another,
though it was against both course and kind.
Then like a father will I, come to check my filly,
for her gadding forth without my leave:
And if she repent it, I am well contented,
home again my darling to receive.

div1.stage: exit into the Castell…

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Lord Powesse, you may guess by the song who this is.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: If the other was Llwellen as thou saidst,
I doubt then this Ranulphe Earl of Chester,
Or some devise figured by thee for them,
to fright us when we are in surest safety.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Content ye Lords, the fathers being by,
you may be sure nothing shall go awry.
Here comes another, listen what he is.

div1.stage: ffrom vnder the Stage the third Antique.

sp.speaker: 3 Antique.
sp.l: you that seek to sunder love,
learn a lesson ere you go:
And as others pains do prove,
so abide yourselves like woe.
for I find, and you shall feel:
selfsame turn of fortunes wheel.
Then if wrong be repayed:
say deserved mends is made.

div1.stage: exit into the Castell.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.p: what say ye to Earl Moorton, Prince Griffin? like ye his company or no?

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Come Iohn, thou lovest to jest, I persuade me it is not so.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: Tush no such matter, this antique disguise,
Is but to give the Brides a good morrow so soon as they rise.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: And to make you despair the course of his art,
he gives these names to every several part.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: what another yet? who should this be?

div1.stage: The fourth out of a tree, if possible it may be.

sp.speaker: 4 Antiq….
sp.l: you stole my love, fie upon ye, fie,
you stole my love, fie fye-a.
guest you but what, a pain it is to prove,
you for your love would dye-a.
And henceforth never longer,
Be such a crafty wronger.
But when deceit takes such a fall,
Then farewell sly devise and all.
you stole my love, fie upon ye fie,
you stole my love, fie fye-a.

div1.stage: exit into the Castell.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.p: My Lord of Pembrooke? may it be possible? by my faith we looked for no such guests: Nay then I will in to make up the mess.

div1.stage: exit into the Castell, & makes fast the dore

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: what meaneth Iohn by this mad merry humour?
he named the Prince Llwellen, and the Earl of Chester,
the Earls of Moorton and of Pembrook; both your Rivals
It seems he would entice us to believe,
that in these antique shows of quaint devise,
they severally are entered the Castle.
It is hard for us to judge of his intent

div1.stage: Enter Iohn a Kent talking with his boy.

sp.speaker: S Griffin.
sp.l: here now he comes again, but not from forth the Castle:
I will be so bold as break his serious talk,
for these devices make me much misdoubt,
further than I as yet will seem to speak on.
Now gentle Iohn, shall we entreat to know,
the meaning of your merry antique show?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: what show my Lord? what meaning should I tell?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: why Iohn those antiques went into the Castle.
four was there of them, and each severally,
both danced and sung here very pleasantly.
The first thou toldest us was the Prince Llwellen,
The second, noble Ranulphe Earl of Chester,
whom thou hadst brought to grace this day withal.
Moorton and Pembrook were the other twain,
In all which Iohn, I know thou didst but fain.
then more at large
why Lords, I pray ye say,
this instant, saw ye me today?

sp.speaker: …len.
sp.l: Saw thee sweet Iohn? I pray thee leave this jesting,
thy feigned strangeness makes these Lords amazed.
didst thou not first set ope the Castle gate?
and then from sundry places issued forth,
the skipping antiques, singing several songs,
as lovers use, that have endured some wrongs?
And when they all were entered at the gate,
thou followedest, seeming then to bar it fast.
whence now thou comest, to make us more admire:
I cannot guess, tell us, I thee desire.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Master, I will credit ye, because you speak it.
But on my faith, all this is strange to me.
My boy and I have for these two hours space,
been greatly busied in another place,
To tell ye truth, against the Brides should rise,
to sport them with some pleasing vanities.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Then Iohn let us in for fear of treachery,
my heart misgives there is some villainy.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: The gate is fast my Lords, bound with such charms,
as very easily will not be undone.
I hope the learned Owen Glenderwellin,
is not come hither in the Lords behalf,
that are your Rivals, and at this advantage:
hath overreached me, when I least misdoubted.
Is it not he, I cannot guess the man.

div1.stage: Enter Iohn a Cumber on the walles lyke Iohn a Kent

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: My Lords, see one appeareth on the walls.
It is Iohn a'Kent, how? Iohn a'Kent is here.
Some sly Magician hath usurped thy shape,
and this day made us all unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: whatever thou be, I charge thee tell thy name.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: My name is Iohn, what sayst thou to the same?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I would thou wert the Iohn that I could wish

sp.speaker: Cumber
sp.l: If Iohn a'Cumber? then the same it is.
In thy proud thoughts Iohn, did I hear thee say,
thou wantedest one to thwart thy deep designs,
laid cunningly to countercheck this love,
because it should not take success so soon.
And me thou namedest, friendly, or how I care not,
here am I now. And what those Lords have told thee,
is very true, thine eyes shall witness it.
Sound music, while I show to Iohn a'Kent,
those hither come, for whom he never sent.

div1.stage: whyle the musique playes, enters on the walles Llwellen Chester wth his Countesse, Moorton with Sydanen, Pemb. with Marian, Oswen and Amerye.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Ah Iohn, if these be not illusions,
but the same parties, all our hope is dashed.
Llewellen, Ranulphe and our hateful foes,
help Iohn, or now afresh begins our woes.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: And are ye taken tardy in your shames?
Proud Southwales Prince, and overdaring Powesse?
See now the issue of your enterprise,
requites ye with your well-deserving merits,
And my Sydanen thus restored again,
shall with Earl Moorton safely now remain

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Madam, I judged you guilty in this wrong,
till Iohn a'Cumber here resolved the doubt.
Now Powesse brag of thy late gotten conquest,
Let Iohn a'Kent with all the wit he hath,
restore thee Marian if he can from me.
Here Earl of Pembrook, take her, she is thine,
And thank kind Iohn whose cunning is divine.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Thanks unto him, and you most noble Lord,
And shame to them, such as their deeds deserve,
that would have severed me from my sweet choice.
I hope here is one hath met with Iohn a'Kent
To teach him how true love he doth prevent

sp.speaker: Mooreton
sp.l: was there no way to yield your love success,
but by that fellows silly practises?
let him hereafter meddle with his mates,
here is one hath given me Marian back again
let him attempt to fetch her if he dare.

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: was ever Lady wronged thus before?
Marian thou knowest my mind, I say no more.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Sweet Cousin, what we may not now impart,
here let us bury it, closely in our heart.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: This sudden change hath altered quite your hope.
what was at first concluded, now must be,
Cousin and daughter, help none else ye see.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Now Iohn without, listen to Iohn within,
the marriage thou appointedest for those Lords,
shall be effected now with these two Lords.
And for they would not let us be their guests,
They nor thyself gets any of our feasts,
In mockery wish for me another day,
So fare ye well, we have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Good Iohn within, hear Iohn without a little,
winners may brag, losers have leave to speak.
under my shadow have you done all this,
much greater cunning had it been thine own.
As yet thou dost but rob me of myself,
Good honest Ihon, let me behold thyself.
Perhaps my shape makes thee thus boldly vaunt,
and arms thee with this ableness of skill,
whereas thine own being insufficient,
may make thee fear to deal with Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Lords and fair Ladies, go disport yourselves,
about the walks and gardens of this Castle.
And for thou weenest so gaily of thyself,
within this hour Iohn I will meet with thee,
in mine own shape, upon this Castle green,
where I will dare thee, and out-dare thee too,
in whatsoever Iohn a'Kent can do.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I take thy word, Ladies to you alone,
wish I all good, but to the others, none.

div1.stage: they discend.

sp.speaker: S G riffin.
sp.l: why say sweet Iohn, what shall betide us now?
Now are we worse than ere we were before.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Sirrah, get ye to the back gate of the Castle,
and through the key hole quickly wring thee in,
mark well, and bring me word what stratagem,
this cumbering Iohn means next to enterprise
for I am sure he will not leave me so,
At least I mean, not him, away then, go.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: I fly Sir, and am there already

div1.stage: exit boy.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: No comfort Iohn? what standest thou all a-mort?
it is only we that have the greatest cause.
Thou canst I know cope with this Iohn a'Cumber
and master him, maugre his utmost skill,
if thou wilt search into thy deep conceits.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: Iohn, I myself have oft times heard thee wish,
that thou mightst buckle with this Iohn a'Cumber.
Come is he now to all our deep disgrace,
except thou help it ere he scape this place.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Master, what? he that went beyond the devil,
And made him serve him seven years prenticeship:
is it possible for me to conquer him?
it is better take this foil, and so to end.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: why then our Ladies this day shall be wed,
If or thou canst or wilt not stand us now in stead.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Nay there is no wedding toward, that I can see,
And when it is done, yet here it must not be.
Content yourselves, and walk the woods about,
here is no getting in, we are fair locked out.
I cannot tell, but if I hit aright
for walking here all day, I will make them some walk all night
Be gon I pray ye, I must be alone
Come on Sirrah, tell me, what news?

sp.speaker: …mp.…
sp.l: Sir, yonder is great preparation for a play,
which by the shadows of the Lords and Ladies,
here on the green shall forthwith be enacted.
And Iohn a'Cumber's whole intent herein,
Is that yourself shall see before your face,
his art made currant to your deep disgrace.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But where is the Countess, Marian and Sydanen?
they are not in the Castle, that I know.

sp.speaker: Shrimpe.
sp.l: Earl Chesters son, and young Lord Amerye
are merrily conducting them to Chester,
And thither will the Lords themselves this night,
when they have seen this play in your despite.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Be gon, and bring the Ladies back again,
with them likewise are sent to be their guides,
Stay with them at the Chestnut tree hard by
till I come for them. Now bestir thee Iohn,
for in thy play I purpose to make one.

div1.stage: exit.
Enter Iohn a Cumber in his owne habit, with him Turnop Hugh, and Thomas the tabrer.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: do ye hear Sir? we can be content as it were to furnish ye with our facility your play or interlude, marry where ye would us to flout, scoff and scorn at Iohn a'Kent, for my part, let Hugh Sexton and Thomas Tabrer do as they see occasion, I am not to mock him, that is able to make a man a Monkey in less than half a minute of an hour.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: I will tell ye what Sir, if it be true that is spoken, marry I will not stand to it, a man were better deal with the best man in the country, than with Master Iohn a'Kent, he never goes abroad without a bushel of devils about him, that if one speak but an ill word of him, he knows it by and by, and it is no more, but send out one of his devils, and where is the man then? nay, God bless me from him.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.l: Hark ye Sir, you are a Gentleman, and we will do as much for Lord, the Earl as poor man may do, If it be to do or say anything against himself, or any other, we will do it, marry Thomas Taberrer will never meddle with Mr. Iohn, no, not I.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: why silly souls, I will be your warrantise
Iohn shall not touch ye, do the best he can,
I will make ye scorn him to his very face.
And let him venge it, how he will or dare

div1.stage: En… Iohn a K…t listning.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.l: By my troth Sir, ye seem an honest man, and so faith, could ye be as good as your word, there be that perhaps would come somewhat roundly to ye. Indeed Sir, Master Iohn hath dealt but even so so with me in times past, hark ye Sir, I never kissed wench or played the good fellow, as sometimes ye know flesh and blood will be frail, but my wife hath known on it ere I came home, and it could not be but by some of his flying devils.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Nay I could tell ye other things beside,
what daily wrongs he doth unto ye all,
which for they ask some leisure to report,
I will urge no more, but that ye join with me,
such an action as I have in hand,
when you shall see him so disabled,
not daring to offend the worst of you,
as henceforth will he hyde his head for shame,
we will make him such a scoffing jesting game.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: But shall he neither send his devils to pinch us? nor do any other harm if we do as you bid us?

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: hark me, I will make him fret himself to death,
with very anger that he cannot touch ye,
Bob, buffet him, do him what wrong ye will,
And fear not I will defend ye by my skill.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: well Sir, I will stand by and give aim, and if I see them speed well, I will bring ye such a crewe of wenches on whom his devils have told lies and tales, that your heart would burst to hear how they will use him

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: why this is excellent, you fit me now.
Come in with me, I will give ye apt instructions,
according to the purpose I intend.
That Iohn a'Kent was never so coursed before,
Our time is short, come let us in about it.

div1.stage: exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Poor Iohn a'Kent, here is making rods
Many have done the like, to whip themselves
But Iohn a'Cumber is more wise than so
he will do nothing, but shall take success.
This walk I made, to see this wondrous man,
Now having seen him, I am satisfied.
I know not what this play of his will prove,
But his intent to deal with shadows only,
I mean to alter, we will have the substances.
And lest he should want Actors his play,
Prince Griffin, Lord Powesse and my merry Master,
I will introduce as I shall find due cause.
And if it chance as some of us do look,
One of us Iohns must play beside the book.

div1.stage: exit.

div2.head: Scena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter Shrimp playing on some instrument, a prettie way befo… the Countesse, Sydanen, Marian, Oswen and Amerye.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Madam, this sound is of some instrument,
for two hours space it still hath haunted us,
now here, now there, on each side round about us,
And questionless, either we follow it,
Or it guides us, lest we mistake our way.

sp.speaker: Amerye.
sp.l: It may be that this famous man of Art,
doubting lest Iohn a'Kent should cross our journey,
and seek revenge for his received disgrace:
he by this music doth direct our course,
more readily to hit the way to Chester.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: whatever it be, I would we were at Chester.
My lovely Niece I see is malcontent
So is my Maryan, but what remedy?
when things you see fall out so contrary?

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Aye poor Sydanen, let no more sweet song,
be made by Poet for Sidanen sake,
her fine trim day is turn to black cole night,
and she hath lost her sweetest love delight.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: But let Sydanen cast away this care,
comfort is nearer her than she is aware.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: what say you Cousin? did you speak to me?

sp.speaker: Ma …i an
sp.l: Not I Sydanen, I with you complain
On fortunes spite and over deep disdain

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: But Marian with Sydanen may rejoice,
for time will let them have their own hearts choice.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Pray God amen, O Cousin did you hear,
a voice still buzzeth comfort mine ear.

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: And so mine, but I no shape can see
It is Iohn a'Cumber mocks both you and me

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: Curse on his heart for cumber true love so,
which else had made full end of all our woe.

div2.stage: Enter Sr. Gosselen, Griffin, Powesse and Euan.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: How say ye Lords? now credit Iohn a'Kent.
See where they are, and at the selfsame tree,
where he assured us all of them would be.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: Sweetest Sydanen, how thy happy sight,
makes me forget all former sorrow quite.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: The like doth Marians presence yield to me,
for all griefs past assured felicity.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Listen my Lords, methinks I hear the chime,
which Iohn did promise, ere you should presume:
to venture for recovery of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: The very same, stay till the power thereof,
have laid the sleepy charge on both their eyes,
that should have guided them from hence to Chester.

div2.stage: The boy trips round about Oswen and Amery, sing… chyme, and they the one after the other, lay them vsing very sluggish gestures, the Ladyes amazed… about them.

sp.l: sleep sweetly: sleep sweetly, sweetly take rest,
each go with her choice, where she likes best.
Ladies cheer up your despairing minds, for your friends are near,
that will answer true love in due kind, then never more fear.

sp.speaker: …rimp.
sp.l: Lords take advantage, for they both are fast,
bid Iohn a'Cumber mend this cunning cast.

sp.speaker: Gosselen.
sp.l: fear not good Madam, for you must with me,
to end the joys these lovers long to see.

div2.stage: The chyme playes, & Gosselen wth the Countesse goes turning out.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: And fair Sydanen I dare boldly say,
rather with me will go, than here to stay

div2.stage: The chyme agayne, and they turne out in like manner.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: I not misdoubt, but Marian bears like mind,
this is the way our sweet content to find.

div2.stage: The chyme agayne, and so they.

sp.speaker: Shrimp
sp.l: Sir Euan, follow you the way they take,
for now I must these sleepy Lords awake.
fie Gentlemen, what means this slothfulness?
you sleep securely, while the subtle foe,
hath got your charge, and bred a greater woe.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Lord Amerye, how fell we thus asleep?
My mother, sister, and Sidanen is gon.

sp.speaker: Amery.
sp.l: Canst thou my boy tell which way they have taken?
or by what means they are thus gon from hence?

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: when as my master, Iohn a'Cumber, saw,
how carelessly you did respect your charge,
and lay asleep, while as Sr. Gosselen denvyle,
Prince Griffin, Powesse, and another Knight,
bare hence the Ladies toward proud Iohn a'Kent:
he sent me posting through the dusky air,
to wake ye, and to cause ye follow me,
to fetch them back ere they have got too far.
If then you will speed, follow me presently.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Thanks to thy master, we will follow thee,
to make amends for our fond negligence.

sp.speaker: Shrimp
sp.l: And I will lead ye such a merry walk,
as you thereof shall at more leisure talk. Come Gentlemen.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Kent lyke Iohn a Cumber, with him Llwellen, Chester, Moorton and Pembrook, foorth of the Castell.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lords, take your places as you are appointed.
Though once I minded but to use your shadows,
pardon me now I may employ your persons,
because that your delight shall be the greater,
and his disgrace the more to you apparent:
that durst attempt so bold an enterprise.
Now shall ye see if famous Iohn a'Kent,
be able to avoid disparagement.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: But shall Sydanen and Earl Chesters daughter,
be here in person likewise as we are?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No my good Lord, their figures shall suffice,
because you see they are disconsolate,
And, to speak truth, bear more affection,
To Griffin of Southwales, and the Lord Powesse,
than to Earl Moorton and the Earl of Pembrooke.
whose shadows when those other Lords shall see,
so far estranged from their former course;
how it will quail their hope, yourselves shall judge,
and make poor Iohn a'Kent mad to behold it.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: But long ere this I hope they are at Chester,
and both their guides in safety at my house.

sp.speaker: …ohn.
sp.l: I warrant ye my Lord, they are safe enough,
from Iohn, and all the utmost he can do.
See my good Lord, what I do for your sake,
who only may dispose of me and mine.
I know it Iohn, and should I not confess,
thy kindness to exceed on my behalf:
and guerdon it, I greatly were to blame.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: The like say I, whereof
my thankfulness shall more at large assure thee.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Needless my Lords are all these ceremonies,
for as I further you in loves affairs:
So I expect some credit by mine Art.
Now silence Lords, for all the sports begin,
And see where Iohn a'Kent is first come.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Cumber lyke Iohn a Kent.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: As he that with unsatiate thirst of fame,
pursues an action of some high applause,
to conquer his usurping enemy,
and add renown forever to his deeds:
So Iohn a'Cumber follows his intent,
to conquer, sit, and laugh at Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: what says he? will he laugh himself to scorn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: My Lord, you little think the scope of his intent,
he doth imagine, he hath taken my shape,
and you shall hear him speak, as he were Iohn a'Cumber.
Note all his actions, and, let it suffice,
he will prove himself a fool before your eyes.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: And yet imagine that he scorneth thee?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: why that is all, for Gods sake, sit and see.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Already are my shadows set in order,
for Prince Llwellen, Chester, Pembrooke, Moorton,
And see poor Iohn a'Kent is walking by,
as one that cannot yield a reason why.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: He points to thee, and terms thee Iohn a'Kent,
let him hereafter brag with Iohn a'Cumber:

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: when men of Art thus strive in merriment
it needs must raise meaner wits some wonder.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Begin your Scene, and if he be not vexed,
I doubt not but he shall be with the next.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: fie Iohn a'Kent, what injury is this,
sp.stage: he riseth and goeth to Iohn a Cumber.
sp.l: that thou hast offered to this noble man.
Sydanen, my fair daughter, whom I love,
wouldst thou have wedded to the Southwales Prince,
And broughtest her hither to thy masters Castle,
from whence she was recovered to thy shame.
fie Iohn a'Kent, for this most silly part,
hereafter term thyself no man of Art.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Thy subtle wandering in an Hermits weed,
whereby thou didst seduce my aged wife,
to let her daughter, and my lovely Niece,
sp.stage: suddenly starting to him, after the other hath done
sp.l: walk with her to Saint winifrydes fair spring
to offer up their latest maiden vows,
and thou, like to an hypocrite, their guide.
Say foolish man, what hast thou won hereby:
but such dishonour as will never die?

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: Iohn, Iohn, call thou to mind the Antiques,
that in thy absence got into the Castle,
And over the walls returned unto thy face
the only argument of thy disgrace.
Alas good Iohn, account it then no wonder,
Such is thy luck to deal with Iohn a'Cumber.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: well Iohn a'Kent, wilt thou be ruled by me?
leave wales, leave England, and be seen no more,
this monstrous blemish graven upon thy brow,
will be but grief to us thy country men,
Then seeing that so tardy thou wert catched,
yield him the bucklers that thee overmatched.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: how now? what is this? my shadows taught to speak,
that to my face, they should unto my foe?

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: Shadows prove substance Iohn, thou art too weak,
then like a silly fellow, pack and go.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Speak here to Iohn a'Kent, speak ye to me?

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: we speak to Iohn the fool, and thou art he.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Spirits, I will torture ye for this abuse.

sp.speaker: Moorton
sp.l: Torture thyself
you

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: All poor silly soul, thou mayst appoint,
and all thy pointing is not worth a point.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: whence am I crossed? may it be Iohn a'Kent,
hath overreached me mine own devise?
The more I strive to know, the further off,
I am from compassing what fain I would.
I will sit awhile, and meditate hereon.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: what? in a study? nay I must awake him,
with other things more angry yet must make him.

div2.stage: Enter Sr Gosselen denvyle, Griffin, Powesse, the Countesse Sydanen and Marian.

sp.speaker: S. Gosselen.
sp.l: Alas alas, why droopeth Iohn a'Kent?
Look cheerily man, for see, Earl Chesters wife,
through power of thine incomparable skill,
is back returned from devilish Iohn a'Cumber,
and no man hath the shame but he alone.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: I know this sadness is but thy conceit,
because he crossed thee ere thou wast aware.
But may not this cheer up thy mind again:
that thou hast brought me sweet Sydanen back?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: And here is Marian too, my souls delight,
who but for thee had been Earl Pembrookes bride.
let Iohn a'Cumber's foil then be of force,
sith we enjoy what we can most desire:
to make thee leave this discontented humour.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Sleep I? or wake I? dream I? or do I dote?
Look what I pointed all these shapes to do,
against the man that I do envy most:
they do it to me, and he sits laughing by,
as if there were no Iohn a'Kent but I.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: why frolic Iohn, thy art proves excellent,
let not one simple foil make thee dismay,
thou art revenged unto thine own content,
let Iohn a'Cumber do the worst he may.

sp.speaker: Sydanen.
sp.l: And will sweet Iohn a'Kent not look so sad,
Sydanen will entreat all Britain Poet,
to write large volume of thy learned skill,
for bringing her where she desire to be,
and from that Iohn a'Cumber set her free.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Look what my Cousin saith, the like do I,
and will extol thy fame continually.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Into the Castle then, and frolic there.
I know that Iohn will not stay long behind,
since your success doth answer thus his mind.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: how say ye now my Lord, did not these shadows;
make him half think they were the same indeed?

sp.speaker: …Llwellen
sp.l: whatever they did him, believe me friend,
but that I more rely upon thine art,
than the opinion this hath raised me:
I should have sworn that that was my Sydanen.

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: In sooth my Lord, I jump with your conceit.
And trust me I was not a little moved,
Prince Griffins shape so led her by the hand:
but that I credit art, more than mine eye.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: will ye believe me? but that Iohn is by,
And doth all this to plague yon Iohn a'Kent:
these semblances would make me much misdeem.
Pardon me Iohn, for love is full of fear,
and such illusions neither please eye not ear.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Then well fare me that differ from you all.
should I have took that shadow for my Countess?
or else the other for my daughter Marian?
Nay, what he did already so resolves me,
that I am dreadless now of Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I thank ye good my Lord, so hold ye still,
for Iohn is no Iohn I see without good skill.
There is one fit more of merriment behind,
that if it hit right, will serve him his kind.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: A pause masters, a pause, we are not come only to do somewhat else beside, for we are of the nick nock Iohn a'Kent, if the honest Gentleman word.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.p: As good as his word? why look ye yonder where he stands honours worship, even as he said he would. he nods his head at as one would say, Masters, fall to your business, or do that ye come for

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: Good Lord look how Iohn a'Kent sits a brown study as it were, who begin now? come let us know that.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: who shall begin? what a question is that? let maid Marian have the flirt at him, to set an edge on our stomachs, and let me alone in to jerk it after her.

sp.speaker: Spurling.
sp.p: Now by my troth well advised good neighbour Turnop, I will turn her to him if he were a far better man than is, to him, to him, touch him roundly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: what? think ye I am afraid of him? i'faith Sir no. Precise Iohn, or rather peevish peeled paltry Iohn, dost thou remember how many injuries from time to time thou hast done me? first sending thy devils to tell lies and tales of me, then making my dame to cudgel me, and lastly to pinch me black and blue when I never offended thee, for which I defy thee to thy face, and dare thee to meet me any place.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: Hear ye Sir? you Sir, as one would say, good man you Sir, because brevity is best in such a queasy action, it is concluded or conditioned among us that have some authority in this case, that because our Morris lacks a fool, and we know none fitter for it than you Mr. Iohn here is a coat spick and span new, it never came on any man's back since it was made, therefore for your further credit, we will give you of it, and where we took ye for a wise man before, we are contented to account of ye as our fool forever hereafter.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: In witness whereof, we the youths of the parish, put it on ye with
our own hands. Nay, never strive or wonder, for thus we are appointed by great Iohn a'Cumber.

sp.speaker: Turnop.
sp.p: At it now Thomas lustily, and let us jerk it over the green, seeing we have got such a goodly fool as Mr. Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: why this will make poor Iohn a'Kent stark mad,
and questionless he will never more show his face,
to be reproved with this deep disgrace

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Lords, sit ye still, I will come again anon,
I am prettily revenged on Cumbering Iohn.

div2.stage: Enter Shrimpe leading Oswen and Amery about the tree.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: were ever men thus led about a Tree?
still circling it, and never getting thence?
My brains do ache, and I am grown so faint,
that I must needs lie down on mere constraint.

sp.speaker: Amery.
sp.l: This villain boy is out of doubt some spirit,
still he cries follow, but we get no further,
than a ring to dance about this tree.
In all my life I never was so weary.
follow that list, for I can go no longer.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.l: There lie and rest ye, for I think your walk,
hath not been altogether to your ease.
Now I must hence, I hear my masters call,
it stands upon the push of opening all.

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Lord Amery, is not yon my father?
the Prince Llwellen, Moorton and Earl Pembrook?

sp.speaker: Amery.
sp.l: It is they indeed, O let us call to them,
to try if they can get us from this tree.
Help Prince of wales, ah help us Earl of Chester,
Or else thy son and I are like to perish.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Oswen my Son? and young Lord Amery?
shadows they be not, for it is they indeed.
Tell me, ah tell me, wherefore lie ye here?
where are the Ladies that you had charge?

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: Ah speak young Lords, my heart doth dread some ill,
ye look so ghastly, and so full of fear.

sp.speaker: Oswen
sp.l: Lend us your aid to raise us on our feet,
that we may get from this accursed
unhappy news.
No ill to my Sidanen, then I care not,
Be Marian well, be what it may beside.
where is the villain boy, that thus misled us?
Boy was he not, but questionless some fiend,
that hath tormented us, as never was like.

sp.speaker: …ellen.
sp.l: Ask for no boys ask for no fiends or furies,
But tell me quickly, where is my Sydanen?
living or dead, or how she is bereft ye?

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: Briefly to answer all of ye together,
Nor of my mother, Marian or Sydanen.
lies it in us to tell ye what is become,
other than this, as it was told to us,
That Griffin, Powesse and Sr. Gosselen denvyle,
rescued them from us, how or when we know not,
so said a devil or boy sent to us from Iohn a'Cumber.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Cumber pulling of his foole coat, lyke Kent still.

sp.speaker: Cumber
sp.l: from me young Lords? alas you were deceived,
as you likewise, and all have been together.
Look not so strange Lords, deem not me Iohn a'Kent,
that his stead have been so much misused,
scorned by you, then flouted by the Ladies,
last made a fool here in a morris dance,
and all prepared against him, turned on myself
In brief then to abridge all further wonder,
yonder is Iohn a'Kent, here Iohn a'Cumber.

div2.stage: Iohn a Kent his owne habit, denvyle, Griffin, Powesse, Euan, Countesse, Sydanen, Marian and Shrimp on the walles.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Now Iohn within, may speak to Iohn without,
And Lords to you that frumped him so finely.
Once you were here, and shut us out of door,
you had these Ladies, but ye could not keep them.
where are those twain that danced about the Tree?
Look on your Minstrel here Sirs, this was he.
But as for you Iohn, that usurped my shape,
And promised you would meet me on the green,
O you were busied too much with your play,
but you know best who went the fool away.
That I am quit with thee thou wilt confess?

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: I do Iohn, for it were shame to yield thee less,
but I may live to meet with ye hereafter.
I pray thee Iohn, shall we have one cast more?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: So thou wilt deal wiser than thou didst before.
Promise me one thing Lords, and you shall see,
I will offer him more odds, than he dare me.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: Let us hear it Iohn, and as we like, we will answer.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: It is so reasonable, you cannot deny me.
fain would ye that your daughters were combined,
sacred wedlock with those noble Lords.
Promise me that it shall be done this day,
without more dallying, I will deliver them,
to Iohn a'Cumber, so he will bestow,
his very deepest skill to make it sure.
But if he fail, and be my luck to speed,
to cease contention, and confess him foiled,
As I will do the like, if he prevail.

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: I am agreed, what says my Lord of Chester?

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: The motion is so good, that I consent.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Lords and fair Ladies, you likewise agree,
to take your fortune howsoever it be?

sp.speaker: O mnes.
sp.l: we do.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Then, not so churl-like, as when you were Lords,
Of this our Castle, to allow no favour,
but even to hunger starve us at the door,
Enter all freely, and took part with us,
cheer, for some of you have need.
And afterward ere night we mean to try
who shall have conquest, either he or I.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Bravely resolved Iohn, I must needs commend thee
thou wilt have the worst if fortune but befriend me .

div2.head: Scena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter the Abbot of Chester reading a letter, & one of

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.l: My honest friend, this letter from thy Lord,
shows that the marriages, so long deferred,
between the Ladies and their several suitors:
must now at length be finished this day.
And at this Abbey is the place appointed.
further he saith, that all the Abbey gates,
not only must be fast, but strongly manned,
with his own guard appointed for the purpose,
that none may issue forth, or enter in,
but such as first must by himself be seen.
what? is there danger of prevention?
or that resistance will be offered?

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: danger there is, but what, in sooth I know not,
Lord Abbot, I have performed my charge to you,
I must go warn his guard in readiness,
and then return to certify my Lord.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.l: Assure his honour, what he hath referred,
unto my trusty care and secrecy
in every point shall answer his content.
Our Lord forbid, but he should here command,
that is our patron, and so good an Earl.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.l: his honour will be thankful for this kindness,
which I will not fail at full to let him know.

sp.speaker: Abbot
