sp.l: febrile my friend, I will about my business straight,
and against his coming give my due attendance.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Kent, denvyle, Griffin and Powesse.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin.
sp.l: would any man but you have been so fond,
to yield the Ladies, when we might have kept them?
poor souls, with what unwillingness they went,
pray God this rashness all we not repent.

sp.speaker: P…wesse.
sp.l: what though that once ye proved too hard for him?
still are ye certain of the like success?
Remember how he crossed us at first,
once warned, doth make a man to dread the worst.

sp.speaker: denvyle.
sp.l: I will suspend my judgment in this case,
and rather hope, than fear what may befall.
Once this I know, it will go wondrous hard,
Ere Iohn a'Kent be in his purpose bard.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: fear you, hope you, for my part, I will do neither,
but track his steppes that treads the way before,
to do the thing he can undo no more.
These weddings then must be at Chester Abbey,
the Gates whereof most strongly will be manned,
Entrance there is allowed at none but one,
And Iohn a'Cumber there must be the Porter,
It is very like then, none of you get in.
And yet i'faith it would be very pretty,
to prove his eyesight, whether he do know,
the men that should be let in, yea or no.
would not you laugh to see him let you in,
and keep them out that should his wager win?

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: O that were excellent, might it be so,
and if thou list, doubtless it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lord Powesse, what think you?

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Even as Prince Griffin, so sweet Iohn
thou art the man mayst make us live or die

sp.speaker: denvyle.
sp.l: If it should fall out so successfully,
beside the endless that thou shalt win
Iohn a'Cumber's foil will be the
shall be,
Iohn a'Cumber even himself say no.
But how can we disguise ourselves so soon,
every point like Mooreton and Earl Pembrook?
otherwise of force we must be known?
Tush we will no shapes, nor none of these disguisings,
they heretofore served both his turn and mine,
As ye are, so shall ye pass the gate.
And for the blame shall not rely alone,
on poor Iohn Cumber, when the fault is spied,
albeit his skill will be the less thereby:
The Prince Llwellen, and the Earl of Chester,
shall both be by, and grant as much as he.
Nay more, themselves shall bring ye to the Chapel,
and at their hands shall you receive your Brides.
If this I do not ere two hours be spent,
Never let me be called more Iohn a'Kent.

sp.speaker: Powesse.
sp.l: Ah peerless Iohn, with love, with life and lands,
will we requite this kindness at thy hands.

sp.speaker: S. Griffin
sp.l: And sing sweet Sonnets in thy endless praise,
while our fair loves and we enjoy our days

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Let us away, it is upon their coming.
for they think long until the deed be done,
wherby Iohn hopes his credit will be wun.

div2.stage: Enter Llwellen, Chester, Countesse, Sydanen, Marian, Oswen, Amery, Iohn a Cumber, and Abbot.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: fear not my Lord, myself have been about,
and seen the gates manned as they ought to be,
with spies beside that shall regard the walls.
And with the Abbot have I taken this order,
Only this gate shall serve for entrance.

sp.speaker: Llwellen.
sp.l: But by your leave my Lord, we will entreat,
that Iohn a'Cumber, till it be dispatched,
will sit as porter, then we may be sure,
that practise Iohn a'Kent whatever he dare,
while he is there the less need be our care.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Alas my Lords, I see what he intends,
to come in person like this reverend Abbot,
thereby to get Griffin and Lord Powesse.
but therein I will prevent him, fear ye not.
father take you the Ladies to your charge,
and with the Countess lead them to the Chapel
you twain will stay until the Bridegrooms come.
then afterwards let all the charge be mine.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: Come lovely Niece and Marian, wend with me,
this day will end the griefs wherein you be.

sp.speaker: Sydanen
sp.l: But may it prove as poor Sidanen wish,
else her heart cares will far surmount her bliss.

sp.speaker: Marian
sp.l: Now Iohn a'Kent if ever thou showedest skill,
do it at this instant, and our joys fulfil.

sp.speaker: Llwellen.
sp.l: I wonder that these Lords do stay so long,
so soon as we they said they would be here.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn a Kent a loof of, Griffin and Lord Powesse.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Go on and fear not, now Iohn we shall see,
if ye can help your eyes infirmity.

sp.speaker: Chester
sp.l: O here they be, fie Lords why stay ye so?
the other would have made more haste I know.

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Be thou their guide, go, quickly make an end,
and then let Iohn a'Kent my skill commend.
O rare Magician that hast not the power,
to beat aside a silly dazzling mist,
which a mere abc scholar in the art,
can do it with the least facility.
But I will ease him when the other come,
To see how then he will bestir himself.
my Lord that there
me
I had not parted with them but
By thy leave Iohn, say, are

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: Alas, alas, hath cunning Iohn
no wiser way than this to
Go ask of him whether the
and he will say they are wedded

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: wedded? to whom? I hope

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: To them whose counterfeit
to noble Earl Pembrook

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Are not we they? what?

sp.speaker: Cumber.
sp.l: however I am, no passage
for you or him, although he

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: why Gentlemen, can ye
Is this the man whose
to face ye down ye be

sp.speaker: Cumber
sp.l: why how now Lords,

sp.speaker: Llwellen
sp.l: At that which now is
Prince Griffin and
unto our daughter
we took them

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: here you my
while you
you come

sp.speaker: Moorton.
sp.l: Oswen,

sp.speaker: Oswen.
sp.l: you

sp.speaker: Amery
sp.l: had been to have wronged them.
do the like confess,
Sydanen never the less.
as toward me you meant,
thanke thee Iohn a'Kent.
must yeeld her too
you had so much to do.
make ye waste the time in vain,
as this day requires,
, be not thou displeased,
least these amorous cares hath eased.
to be disgraced by thee,
both of mine and me.
, and ever more hereafter
vow continual love.
fortune was not evil,
overmatched the devil.
